titleStmt.title: New ternary equi-atomic refractory medium-entropy alloys with tensile ductility: Hafnium versus titanium into NbTa-based solution

funder.orgName: National Natural Science Foundation of China

affiliation.orgName: University of Chinese Academy of Sciences
Department of Materials Science and Engineering

analytic.title: New ternary equi-atomic refractory medium-entropy alloys with tensile ductility: Hafnium versus titanium into NbTa-based solution

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: Medium-entropy alloys Solid solution hardening Refractory metals Tensile properties BCC structure

div.p: We demonstrate that based on NbTa as the base solution, ternary equiatomic HfNbTa and TiNbTa single-phase body-centered-cubic (BCC) solid solutions are achieved at arc-melted alloy ingots. These add interesting new members into the group of ternary refractory medium-entropy alloys (RMEAs), previously available only in NbTiZr. Moreover, HfNbTa and TiNbTa are the first two ternary RMEAs that exhibit tensile ductility, with HfNbTa having a combination of yield strength and tensile strain on par with its high-entropy counterpart, the Senkov alloy TiZrHfNbTa. We also show that alloying Hf into the base NbTa solution manifests a much higher strengthening potency compared with Ti. This difference can be rationalized using empirical parameters and models accounting for the size and modulus misfits among constituent elements.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: With multiple principal elements, high-entropy alloys (HEAs) offer opportunities to discover interesting alloys in an extended compositional space [1][2][3][4]. Among such complex concentrated alloys (CCAs), a family of them are composed of five or more refractory metals in equal proportion, including titanium, zirconium, hafnium, vanadium, niobium, tantalum, molybdenum and tungsten, etc. [5][6][7][8][9][10][11]. These are grouped as the refractory high-entropy alloys (RHEAs), which are single-phase body-centered cubic (BCC) solid solutions. These RHEAs exhibit a high yield strength (σ y ) in the range of 900-1600 MPa at room temperature (RT). RHEAs are currently of much interest, because they may offer sufficiently high strength at elevated temperatures to rival superalloys [12], and are potentially useful for biomedical implants [13][14][15][16][17].

A sore spot with the RHEAs reported so far is that at RT they usually are ductile only in compression. Tensile ductility is more important for applications bearing high loads and for forming and shaping operations, but is unfortunately rarely available from RHEAs. In this regard, the RHEAs in the Ti-Zr-Hf-Nb-Ta system stand out, as they are the only ones showing appreciable tensile ductility [18][19][20]. The as-cast BCC equiatomic TiZrHfNbTa alloy shows a σ y of 820-835 MPa [18] (which can be further elevated via subsequent cold-rolling and annealing [19]), together with a tensile elongation to failure of ∼9%. This level of RT ductility is acceptable for certain applications. Our work presented below therefore focuses on alloys in the Ti-Zr-Hf-Nb-Ta sub-family of RHEAs.

Rather than dealing with all combinations in this sub-family, our next step is to further narrow down the scope of our study to a subset: ternary medium-entropy alloys (MEAs), i.e., refractory MEAs composed of three elements out of Ti-Zr-Hf-Nb-Ta. Ternary MEAs are interesting for at least the following four reasons. First, reducing the number of principal elements makes the system simpler but does not necessarily sacrifice mechanical properties. For example, the quaternary TiZrHfNb medium-entropy alloy (MEA) in its as-annealed state exhibits a σ y of 879 MPa and an elongation of ∼15% [21], a combination comparable to its higher-order TiZrHfNbTa quinary alloy. In other words, the absence of Ta did not adversely affect tensile properties. Similar situation has also been noticed in the face-centered cubic (FCC) HEAs: in the family based on FeCoCrNiMn (the Cantor alloy) [22], it turns out that the ternary CoCrNi MEA presents the highest σ y , ductility and fracture toughness [23], better than quaternary FeNiCoCr or NiCoCrMn, and the quinary Cantor alloy. As such, the tensile properties of MEA/HEA are not simply determined by the number of components or simply an algebraic interpolation of constituents. The stremlined ternary MEA can even bear representative properties typical of a family of HEAs. Second, the smaller number of constituent elements makes it easier to understand the thermodynamics and phase diagrams in the system, and more amenable to modeling research on mechanisms in general. Third, the optimization of strength and ductility, particularly when at high https://doi.org/10.1016/j.intermet.2019.01.004 Received 27 November 2018; Accepted 3 January 2019 temperatures where precipitates and chemical order are involved, would be more manageable for the ternary MEA than the counterpart higher-order system. Fourth, limiting the participating constituents may save the cost associated with certain expensive elements and the complexity associated with processing of elements with large disparity in melting temperatures and chemical affinity.

Then, which three elements should we choose among Ti-Zr-Hf-Nb-Ta for our pursuit of ternary RMEAs? We next remove Zr from the mix, leaving the selection pool to be Ti-Hf-Nb-Ta. The reason not to involve Zr is that, in the presence of Nb-Ta, previous studies have already found Zr [24] to dramatically reduce the tensile ductility of NbTa. The loss in ductility in fact is related to the drastic rise of the ductile to brittle transition temperature (T BDT ) when the alloying element Zr is overconcentrated in pure Nb [15,25].

Besides, an interesting perspective is that Ti-Hf-Nb-Ta offers an opportunity to examine the strengthening potency of a "solute", Hf versus Ti, in the base binary BCC Nb-Ta "solvent". This perspective arises from the realization that due to the similar atomic size (r Ta = 143.0 pm, and r Nb = 142.9 pm) between BCC Nb and Ta [26], the two elements form continuous solid solution in the phase diagram, such that the equiatomic NbTa solid soluiton can be assumed to be a psudo solvent. One can then contrast the effects of adding another component, i.e., solute Ti (i.e., 33%Ti in the NbTa base solution) versus Hf on the mechanical properties. This line of thoughts greatly simplifies our route towards ternary RMEAs: Hf combined with NbTa to produce HfNbTa, versus Ti onto NbTa to arrive at TiNbTa, as well as a comparison of the two scenarios.

In the experiments the follow, we use arc-melting to produce equiatomic alloys, from the NbTa binary to the ternary TiNbTa, HfNbTa. Both Ti and Hf are also added to form (TiHf)NbTa, and this quaternary alloy will be mentioned only in passing and included in our comparison. Our focus is on ternary RMEAs. First, the microstructures will be studied to observe if single-phase BCC RMEAs can be obtained, and compared with the phases predicted by thermodynamic phase diagram calculations (CALPHD). Second, standard tensile tests of these alloys will be used to gauge the tensile strength and ductility of the RMEAs achieved, and compare the strengthening potency of Hf versus Ti. Third, the potency of solution strengthening due to Ti or Hf will be semi-quantitatively analyzed using an empirical parameter and a previously postulated model. Fourth and finally, the failure mechanism of the eventual tensile fracture will be compared for the RMEAs.

div.head: Experimental
div.p: Commercial elemental bulk materials with purity higher than 99.9% (in weight percentage) were used as starting materials for alloy ingot fabrication. A series of alloys with equi-atomic composition of NbTa, TiNbTa, HfNbTa and TiHfNbTa were processed using arc melting. The arc-melted ingots in weight of about 50 g were fabricated under a Tigettered argon atmosphere in a water-cooled copper hearth. They are subjected to several remelting and flipping runs to ensure compositional homogeneity. The effective cooling rate during the solidification of the ingot is on the order of 1 K/s.

Crystalline phases in the as-cast alloys were identified using x-ray diffraction (XRD), on a Rigaku D/max 2500 diffractometer (Rigaku, Tokyo, Japan) with monochromatic Cu K α radiation. Step-scanning mode was used for scanning within a range of relevant diffraction angle (2θ) to ensure the accuracy of determined position of diffraction lines. Lattice parameters of crystalline phases with BCC structure were determined by fitting the whole diffraction line profiles using pseudo-Voigt function. As-cast microstructures of the alloys were characterized with a Quanta 600 scanning electron microscope (SEM) (FEI, Eindhoven, the Netherlands) and electron backscatter diffraction (EBSD) attached on Supra 55 SEM (Zeiss, Germany). Chemical composition and elemental mapping on cross-section surfaces of the as-cast alloys were analyzed using an EDX detector attached on SEM. Dog-bone shaped tension samples were taken from the central portion of the arc-melted button-like ingots, with a gauge dimension of 8 mm in length, 2.5 mm in width and 1 mm in thickness. Uniaxial tensile tests were conducted at RT on a 2 kN Instron 5848 micromechanical testing machine (Instron, Norwood, MA) using a laser extensometer. A constant strain rate of 5 × 10 -4 s -1 was used, and at least four specimens were measured for each alloy. Fracture surfaces of specimens after tensile failure were examined on Quanta 600 SEM.

div.head: Microstructure characterization
div.p: Fig. 1 displays XRD patterns of four arc-melted alloys, NbTa, TiNbTa, HfNbTa and TiHfNbTa. It is seen that in all cases, only a BCC phase is detectable. The alloys are therefore a single-phase solid solution, with no intermetallic phases. The lattice parameters, a 0 , of these BCC solid solutions were determined, as listed in Table 1, together with the a 0 value of constituent elements (BCC Ti, Hf, Nb and Ta) for comparison. As BCC-Ti and Hf (β-phase) are stable only at elevated temperatures, their a 0 values at RT are extrapolated from elevated temperature data to RT [6]. As shown in Fig. 1, the diffraction peak positions for the NbTa binary alloy are well in accord with those of its constituent components Nb and Ta, such that the a 0 value of the completely-mixed NbTa alloy is comparable to that of pure Nb and Ta, as shown in Table 1. For the TiNbTa ternary, the positions of three diffraction peaks besides (110) shift slightly toward higher Bragg angles with respect to the binary NbTa phase, giving an a 0 value ∼0.3% smaller. This lattice contraction is attributed to the substitution of soluble Ti atoms with a smaller atomic size (r Ti = 141.8 pm) on the lattice sites of the NbTa solvent. In the case of HfNbTa ternary MEA, the

div.head: Table 1
div.p: Measured lattice parameter, a 0 , and estimate using Vegard's law, a 0 cal , for the four BCC NbTa-based alloys and their constituent elements. positions of all diffraction peaks shift toward lower Bragg angles with respect to the NbTa, due to the incorporation of Hf atoms with larger atomic size (r Hf = 151.4 pm) in the NbTa host lattice, resulting in a lattice expansion of ∼2.6%. Diffraction peaks of the quaternary TiHfNbTa MEA situate in between those of the TiNbTa and the HfNbTa, showing an intermediate a 0 value ∼2.2% larger than that of the TiNbTa, while 0.7% less than that of the HfNbTa. Among these alloys, the HfNbTa MEA exhibits the largest a 0 value of 0.3387 nm, followed by TiHfNbTa (a 0 = 0.3364 nm), NbTa (a 0 = 0.3302 nm) and TiNbTa (a 0 = 0.3291 nm), in a sequence consistent with the decreasing atomic radius of the solute element added.
Using the empirical Vegard's law for ideal solid solution and the concentrations in each BCC phase, the lattice parameter, a 0 cal , is calculated as

where X i and a i are the concentration and lattice parameter of the ith alloying element, respectively, as listed in Table 1 for comparision. The experimentally measured a 0 values for these alloys are comparable with the estimated a 0 cal , with deviations < 0.1%. Fig. 2 shows a plot of the experimental a 0 against the estimated a 0 cal for the four alloys, in which the solid line denotes the iso-line of the two values. All data points locate nearly on this isoline without significant deviation. This suggests that all four equiatomic alloys can be approximated as nearly-random BCC solid solutions, for each overall sample [5,27]. Moreover, an inset in Fig. 2 displays the unit-cell volume of the four alloys for comparison.

With the NbTa binary alloy as benchmark, the incorporation of Ti induces lattice contraction by ∼1%, while the Hf addition induces large lattice expansion by ∼8%. When the Ti and Hf with the same concentration are co-incorporated into the NbTa solvent, lattice expansion (∼6%) dominates. It is reasonable to view the MNbTa (M = Ti, Hf) MEAs as pseudo-binary M-(NbTa) or pseudo-ternary Ti-Hf-(NbTa) solid solutions. Fig. 3 (a)-(d) display EBSD inverse polar figures (IPFs) for the four alloys, taken from the central portion of the as-cast ingots. In all cases, the microstructure is composed of randomly oriented grains with irregular shapes and a broad size distribution ranging from 10 μm to over 1 mm, without any prefered crystallographic texture. Fig. 4 shows the grain areal fraction as a function of grain size. The distribution of grain sizes for NbTa, TiNbTa and TiHfNbTa exhibit similar profiles, with over 70% grains in the range up to 400 μm; the average grain size is 300 μm, 341 μm and 340 μm, respectively. On the other hand, grain sizes below 100 μm account for over 40% in the HfNbTa, with an average grain size of 215 μm. Nevertheless, the grain sizes of all these alloys are rather large, such that their difference in grain size is expected to have little effect on mechanical propeties. Fig. 5 (a)-(d) display SEM images of the four arc-melted alloys, taken from the central portion of the as-cast ingots. Their chemical homogeneity on micrometer scale was characterized using EDX, and listed in Table 2 for comparision. As shown in Fig. 5(a) and (c), the mircrostructures of Ti-free NbTa and HfNbTa are quite uniform, without significant elemental segregation. The global compositions are well in accord with the nominal ones (see Table 2). This finding indicates that the difference in melting temperature (T m ) among Nb (T m = 2750 K), Ta (T m = 3290 K) and Hf (T m = 2506 K) did not bring about the formation of dendrites and elemental segregation in the ascast state. However, in the case of TiNbTa, its as-solidified microstructure consists of two distinct regions with significant heterogeneity, as displayed in Fig. 5(b). The light-contrast dendrites (DR) are enriched with Ta and Nb, whereas the interdendritic regions (ID) are enriched with Ti. The areal fraction of the ID can be estimated to be ∼13% in the entire examined field. Similarly, the TiHfNbTa MEA also manifests a small fraction of dendritic grains, as shown in Fig. 5(d). EDX analysis indicates that the chemical composition of the predominant DR are nearly identical to the nominal one, while the ID with minor fraction is enriched in Ti and Hf. Furthermore, Fig. 5(e)-(p) present the elemental mapping for each constituent in the alloys. It is shown that all elements in NbTa and HfNbTa are homogeneously distributed, while obvious enrichment of Ta and Ti are seen in the areas of DR and ID, respecitvely, for the Ti-containing TiNbTa and TiHfNbTa. Since the melting temperature of Ti (T m = 1941 K) is ∼800 K and ∼1350 K lower than those of Nb and Ta, respectively, it is natural to expect the segregation of higher-T m Nb and Ta in DR and lower-T m Ti in ID. Comparing the ternay HfNbTa with TiHfNbTa, the incorporation of Ti in the HfNbTa MEA appears to enhance the segregation of Hf away from the NbTa solvent into the ID area.

div.head: Comparison with CALPHAD-predicted phases
div.p: To predict the equilibrium phases in the investigated alloys, phase diagrams are calculated using CALPHAD (commercial software Thermo-Calc and TTNI8 database, Version 8.3). Fig. 6 (a)-(d) display the predicted relative mass fraction (wt.%) of phases as a function of temperature for the four alloys. As shown in Fig. 6 (a), the NbTa binary in solid state forms a single BCC phase at all temperatures; this is indeed the only phase observed as shown in Section 3.1. In the TiNbTa ternary, a single BCC phase is stable at temperature > 800 K, decomposing into two solid phases (BCC and HCP) occurs at lower temperatures, as shown in Fig. 6(b). The mass fraction of the two phases is approximately 85 wt% and 15 wt% at 500 K, respectively. Similarly, for the HfNbTa ternary, the high-temperature BCC phase decomposes into another BCC and HCP phases at ∼1400 K, as shown in Fig. 6(c). The mass fraction of the two co-existing phases is ∼60 wt% and ∼40 wt% at 500 K, respectively. As for the TiHfNbTa quaternary, the decomposition of solid phase occurs at ∼1100 K, as shown in Fig. 6(d), with the BCC and the HCP accounting for 55 wt% and 45 wt% at 500 K, respectively.

The predicted HCP phases have not been detected within XRD resolution limit (approximately less than 5 vol%). Only a single BCC phase is found, as shown in Fig. 1. This is because the RMEAs obtained via arc-melting are actually away from thermodynamic equilibrium due to the fast cooling rate (the order of magnitude is ∼1 K/s) from the melts. As such, the formation of HCP phase is suppressed, owing to the lack of sufficient time for atomic diffusion required by the solid phase transformation (i.e. phase separation). As such, the current single-phase BCC structures are metastable. The phase formation in fully-annealed state for these alloys is a subject for future work. NbTa-based alloys at RT. Their tensile properties are summarized in Table 3 for comparison. For the NbTa binary solid solution, its σ y is 246 ± 14 MPa, comparable to that of pure Nb and Ta [28,29], suggesting that mixing of Nb and Ta does not generate pronounced solution hardening, consistent with previous findings [26,30,31]. The tensile strain to failure, ε f , is over 20%, showing the excellent ductility of this alloy. Alloying the NbTa with Ti to form the TiNbTa MEA nearly doubles the σ y to 478 MPa, with only minor reduction of ε f . For ternary HfNbTa, its σ y reaches as high as 847 MPa, a three-fold increase over the NbTa binary. Evidently, alloying with Hf has a much higher strengthening potency than Ti [25]. The HfNbTa RMEA also shows a high σ uts of 889 MPa. However, the ε f is reduced to < 10%. The TiHfNbTa quaternary produces an intermediate σ y of 663 MPa in between the TiNbTa and the HfNbTa, with an ε f similar to the latter. For comparison, Fig. 8 shows a plot of yield strength versus tensile strain for the four investigated alloys, together with the data of highorder Senkov alloy (TiZrHfNbTa HEA) in the as-cast state [18]. As a general trend, the alloy with higher σ y exhibits a trade-off in its lower ductility [32]. It is interesting to note that the ternary HfNbTa RMEA exhibits a yield strength competitive with that of quinary TiZrHfNbTa. At the same time, it also exhibits tensile ductility, on par with the quinary RHEA.

div.head: Tensile properties at room temperature
div.p: In terms of the work-hardening rate seen from the slope of the stress-strain curve in the plastic regime, TiNbTa fares better than HfNbTa, leading to larger uniform elongation. A drawback is that its σ y is < 500 MPa. However, if extended shaping is needed, a high RT strength is not the deciding factor but ductility is. In this sense, this ternary TiNbTa RMEA may be an option for formability.

div.head: Fractography after failure in tension
div.p: Fig. 9(a) and (b) show SEM images of fracture surface after tensile failure for the NbTa binary alloy. The fracture surface seen in Fig. 9(a) presents parallel elongated ridgelines and valleys, ranging from 5 to 30 μm in size, rather than the characteristic of dimpled rupture in conventional ductile metals. Fig. 9(b) displays a zoom-in image of the blocked area in Fig. 9(a), showing nearly-planar facets between ridges and valleys typically 10 μm in width. This type of jagged peak-andvalley morphology is typical in pure Ta after tensile failure at RT [29], which is associated with a process of multistage coalescence. Under successive non-uniform plastic deformation, microvoids occasionally nucleate at specific sites of sub-grains with high-angle boundaries, and subsequently link up along the direction of applied tensile stressing to create diamond-shaped multi-void cavities. These cavities grow and interconnect, transverse to the direction of tensile loading, resulting in final rupture.

Fig. 9(c) shows an SEM image of the fracture surface after tensile failure for the TiNbTa ternary RMEA. The fracture surface exhibits ductile dimples with different sizes less than 5 μm, typical for microvoids coalescence transverse to the direction of tensile loading. On further alloying the TiNbTa with Hf to form the TiHfNbTa quaternary, the fracture surface remains a landscape of ductile dimples, as shown in Fig. 9(c). But, it is noteworthy that its dimple depth becomes shallower in contrast to the TiNbTa, even though the dimples sizes are at the same level.

Fig. 10(a)-(d) display SEM images of fracture surface after tensile failure for the HfNbTa ternary MEA. As shown in Fig. 10(a), the fracture surface is relatively smooth, and contains a number of microcracks with a length scale roughly comparable to the grain sizes. Fig. 10(b) displays a zoom-in image of the area blocked as zone I in Fig. 10(a), in which the cracks nucleate at triple junctions, and then propagate along grain boundaries. Meanwhile, severely-deformed grains are separated from each other, at the intersection of grain boundaries, as shown in Fig. 10(c). Thus, the HfNbTa ternary MEA undergoes intergranular fracture during final unstable failure, partially dominated by the cohesive strength of grain boundaries [33]. Moreover, abundant wavy slip lines appear in the grain boundaries, as shown in Fig. 10(d), suggesting that plastic flow along grain boundaries is sustained for a while to maintain the macroscopic plastic strain. This suggests the Hf has an effect to promote a transition from yielding control to cohesion control in the grain boundaries. The salient fracture features are summarized in Table 4.

div.head: Solid solution hardening in multi-principal element alloys
div.p: As a first approximation for solution strengthening, Senkov et al. [6] applied the Labusch approach. They adopted the picture of pseudobinary solid solution, in which the solutes and solvents were selectively defined for a given BCC TiZrHfNbTa HEA, in terms of the atomic size or modulus misfits between the constituent elements. However, large differences in either atomic size or modulus between constituent elements are inevitable in a given alloy [13,34]. It becomes very difficult to assign the elements as the solutes or the solvents to set up the pseudo-binary solution, resulting in an arbitrary judgement of what role the elements play. Toda-Caraballo et al. [35] proposed a model for solution hardening in HEAs by quantifying the elemental interactions and elastic misfits, via the computation of an interatomic spacing matrix {s ij }. Nevertheless, the results predicted by this model showed a significant deviation from experimental data.

Traditionally, the solid-solution hardening (SSH) in binary solidsolution alloys originates from the interaction of dislocations and the elastic field induced by the atomic size misfit, δ i , and modulus misfit, ′ η i , between the solvent and solute atoms [36,37]. The misfit parameter, ε i , integrating the contribution of both δ i and ′ η i , has been confirmed to be a valid indicator of predicting the SSH effect for a given solute component i. The coupled effect of δ i and ′ η i is expressed as [35,38]:

where the parameter α reflects the difference in interaction forces between the screw-type and edge-type dislocations and the solute atoms; 3 < α < 16 for the screw, and α > 16 for the edge. Generically, the SSH Note: σ y , and ε f are tensile yield strength total tensile strain to failure, respectively. σ uts is the ultimate tensile strength. However, different from conventional dilute solid-solution alloys, for an MEA it is ambiguous to identify the components as solvent or solute, due to their comparable concentration. It has been a challenge to find an indicator for characterizing the SSH effect in HEAs. As indicated by Oh et al. [42] recently, the individual mean atomic distortions are actually small on average (< 1%), while their fluctuations are an order of magnitude larger in a typical FeCoNiCrMn HEA. The local misfit, ε i , of element i with respect to other surrounding atoms should be responsible for the strengthening. Meanwhile, Gypen and Deruyttere [43] argued that the total strengthening effect is related to the synergetic contribution of each constituent element, rather than the simply algebraic additions for multi-component alloys. In other words, the SSH is determined by the overall coupled effect of local misfit of each constituent.
Here we propose a modified misfit parameter, Θ, defined as = ∑ Θ ε X ( )

, akin to the parameter ε X i i 4/3 2/3 previously used for dilute binary solid solutions. ε i follows the description in Eq. ( 2), where the local δ i and ′ η i of element i are determined by the 9-atoms cluster approach of BCC lattice [6], under a picture of hard-sphere dense packing:

div.p: j is the difference in shear modulus between elements i and j, and r i , r j , G i and G j are the radius and shear modulus of elements i and j, respectively. Properties of individual elements involved in the current investigated alloys are shown in Table 5 [28]. and = ∑ G GX i i i , where σ i y and G i are the yield strength and shear modulus of element i, respectively, as listed in Table 6. As shown in Fig. 11, the Δσ G / ss scales with Θ linearly (R 2 = 0.94). With respect to NbTa benchmark alloy, alloying with Ti raises Θ to result in a 6-fold higherΔσ G / ss . In contrast, alloying with Hf in the NbTa host produces an even larger Θ and hence a 15-fold higher Δσ G / ss . In a word, Hf is significantly more potent than Ti, and the SSH intrinsically originates from the overall synergetic misfits between the constituents, as semi-quantitatively captured by the parameter Θ.
In addition, one can project the Young's modulus (E) of BCC solidsolution phases, using estimates under an iso-strain assumption [14].
The estimated E values of our four NbTa-based solid-solution alloys are listed in Table 6 for comparison.

div.head: Validity of the fictive lattice model for SSH in RMEAs
div.p: As detailed in our previous work [14], we proposed an empirical fictive lattice model, as a simple tool to quantify the SSH effect in BCC RHEAs. By defining a fictive unary-like lattice as the nominal solvent and treating all constituent elements as nominal solute, the SSH effectΔσ ss , can be quantified via a combination of Labusch's theory [38] and the approach of Gypen and Deruyttere [43]. The local misfits of each solute are determined via unit-cell clusters with fictive self-pairs as a reference state. This model was successfully applied to describe the SSH in a number of RHEAs [14],

where the misfit parameter, and ε i , is calculated using Eq. ( 2). This model predicts the yield strength in multicomponent RHEAs with a deviation from experimental values of less than 27%, better than the model proposed by Toda-Caraballo et al. [35]. To examine the applicability of the fictive lattice model to the four BCC NbTa-based solidsolution RMEAs, the predicted yield stress values, σ y P , calculated with Eq. ( 5), are listed in Table 6, together with corresponding experimentally-measured yield strength, σ y , and their relative deviations. The σ y P is 17% and 24% lower than the σ y for NbTa and TiNbTa, respectively, and 10% and 28% higher for HfNbTa and TiHfNbTa alloys, respectively. This margin of difference is similar to that for all RHEAs. Graphically,

div.head: Table 5
div.p: Atomic radius, r, shear modulus, G, and yield strength, σ y , of constituent elements in the investigated alloys at room temperature [28]. Note: G is the shear modulus estimated from interpolation of elemental values. E is the Young's modulus estimated using the rule of mixtures in terms of elemental values under iso-strain condition. Fig. 12 shows a plot of the predicted σ y against the experimentallymeasured σ y for the current four NbTa-based RMEAs (solid symbols), together with archived data of RHEAs in the literature (open symbols). Similar to the case of RHEAs, all data of RMEAs are well situated in vicinity of the isoline, suggesting the usefulness of the fictive lattice for depicting the SSH effect in all RHEAs/RMEAs.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: (i) Based on the NbTa ideal solution, via arc-melting we have achieved ternary TiNbTa and HfNbTa that are single-phase BCC RMEAs. Their lattice parameters are well in accord with the Vegard's law. Chemical compositions of the NbTa and HfNbTa alloys are uniform, whereas the dendritic microstructure in the TiNbTa RMEA shows the enrichment of lower-T m Ti in interdendritic regions and of higher-T m Nb and Ta in dendrites. (ii) HfNbTa and TiNbTa are the first ternary RMEAs, the only other one reported so far being NbTiZr [44]. HfNbTa and TiNbTa are also the only two ternary RMEAs that exhibit tensile ductility (NbTiZr merely showed compressive plasticity). Moreover, HfNbTa has a combination of yield strength and tensile ductility comparable with its RHEA counterpart TiZrHfNbTa, the Senkov alloy. The TiNbTa RMEA has a tensile ductility in excess of 20%, while its yield strength is < 500 MPa. (iii) In terms of solution strengthening, alloying with Hf into the base NbTa solution manifests a much higher strengthening potency, compared with Ti. This potency difference can be accounted for by the effects of atomic size and modulus misfits among constituents, scaling linearly with the Θ parameter, = ∑ Θ ε X ( )
. Our previous empirical fictive lattice model is also applicable to these RMEAs, as they appear to fit in with the general strengthening trend for all the RHEAs.

figure.head: Fig. 6 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 6. Plot of mass fraction of equilibrium phases as a function of temperature predicted via CALPHAD for (a) NbTa, (b) TiNbTa, (c) HfNbTa and (d) TiHfNbTa alloys.

figure.head: Fig. 7 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 7. Tensile engineering stress-true strain curves of four NbTa-based alloys at room temperature.

figure.head: Fig. 8 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 8. Yield strength versus tensile strain of four NbTa-based solid-solution alloys, in comparison with that of the Senkov alloy (TiZrHfNbTa).

figure.head: Fig. 9 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 9. SEM images of fracture surfaces after tensile failure for (a) NbTa, (c) TiNbTa and (d) TiHfNbTa alloys. (b) Zoom-in image of the blocked area in (a).

figure.head: Fig. 10 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 10. SEM images of fracture surface after tensile failure for ternary HfNbTa alloy. (a) morphology in low magnification, (b), (c) and (d) zoom-in images of blocked area labeled as I, II and III in (a), respectively.
Fig. 11 displays the normalized potency of SSH, Δσ G / ss , against parameter Θ for the BCC NbTa-

figure.head: Fig. 11 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 11. Normalized potency of solid-solution hardening, Δσ G / ss , versus parameter = ∑ Θ ε X ( ) i i i 2 2/3 for BCC NbTa-based solid-solution alloys.

figure.head: Fig. 12 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 12. Comparison of experimentally-measured σ y with the values predicted using the "fictive lattice" model of SSH, σ y p , for NbTa-based RMEAs (Solid symbols), together with the literature data for RHEAs (Open symbols).

figure.head: Table 2
figure.figDesc: Chemical composition (at.%) determined using EDX analysis for four NbTabased solid-solution alloys.

figure.head: Table 3
figure.figDesc: Tensile properties of BCC NbTa-based solid-solution alloys.

figure.head: Table 4
figure.figDesc: Fractography features and relevant failure mechanism for four NbTa-based solid-solution alloys.

figure.head: Table 6
figure.figDesc: Predicted yield strength, σ y P , using the "fictive lattice" model of SSH, and its deviation from measured σ y , for NbTa-based solid-solution alloys, together with the normalized yield stress, Δσ ss /G.
